head.title: Pink-Slip Party for Escapees From the Dot-Com Disasters

hedline.hl1: Pink-Slip Party for Escapees From the Dot-Com Disasters

abstract.p: Scene during weekly 'pink-slip party' at Rebar in Chelsea section of lower Manhattan, for victims of dot-com downsizing, described; photo (M)

block.p: THE SETTING -- Last week, hundreds of twentysomethings jammed a Chelsea bar, fueling up on $3 bottles of Budweiser, slapping backs and swapping Web site war stories.
It was a scene any of these Internet kids could have envisioned last year, hanging out toasting their soaring stock options.
THE SETTING -- Last week, hundreds of twentysomethings jammed a Chelsea bar, fueling up on $3 bottles of Budweiser, slapping backs and swapping Web site war stories.
It was a scene any of these Internet kids could have envisioned last year, hanging out toasting their soaring stock options.
But now that many Internet companies have gone from start-up to belly up, losing their financing and firing employees, the drinks tend to be tonics to soothe broken dot-com dreams.
In fact, the Chelsea gathering was one of the weekly ''pink-slip parties'' held Wednesday nights at Rebar, at 16th Street and Eighth Avenue, for victims of dot-com downsizing.
THE BUZZ -- There were very few tears in the beer, actually. The mood was like that of a crew that narrowly escaped going down with the ship.

Since these parties started last month, word has spread through e-mail invitations from Allison Hemming, president of Thehired guns.com, a consulting firm for Internet and technology companies. She bills the happy hour as a ''safe haven for dot-com-miserating.''
At last week's party, Jodie Kahn talked like an old hand. She was fired from Grit.net, a Web radio site, in 1998, ''back before it was hip to be downsized,'' she said.

''There's really no stigma anymore to being fired from a dot-com,'' said Ms. Kahn, who said working for a doomed start-up goes like this: ''When you're hired, they tell you, 'This is gonna be so great.' Then when the financing's gone, it's, 'Sorry, we can't afford you anymore.' ''

That's how Carol Huang, one of 140 workers laid off last June by APBnews.com, said it was for her. Back from a monthlong vacation in the Middle East, she is looking for work as a freelance writer ''until I figure out what I'm supposed to do with myself.''
Her friend Judy Dutton said she came to the party ''to feel superior'' since she had a secure job as a senior editor at Cosmopolitan magazine.
''It's such an ego boost to be among so many recently unemployed people,'' she said, laughing.

Of course, the events are a bountiful harvest for recruiters. One of them, Bonnie Halper of Sendresume .com, chatted up several Internet casualties, but said she would find no ''techies'' -- computer programmers and code writers -- this evening.
''You know where they hang out?'' she said. ''Strip clubs. You think I'm kidding, but I'm not. When I go there to recruit them, I have to bring my husband, and he'll only go if I get a lap dance.''

Susana Saja was at her third straight party. Ms. Saja, 27, recently lost her job at Orientation.com, a portal site. ''They never got their third round of financing, and they fired 50 employees in one day,'' she said. ''It was so impersonal.''
